title: A comparison of unamplified and massively multiplexed PCR amplification for murine antibody repertoire sequencing
background: Antibody repertoire sequencing is important for understanding immune responses, but most methods rely on amplification which can introduce biases. This is particularly relevant for spaceflight research where immune system changes occur due to microgravity and radiation exposure.
objective: To compare unamplified sequencing of murine antibody repertoires with commercially amplified methods to assess biases and determine the most reliable approach for immune monitoring in constrained environments.
methods: Comparison of unamplified total RNA sequencing (KSU method) with two commercial amplification methods (Com1 and Com2) using splenic RNA from C57BL/6J mice. Evaluated effects of starting material (mRNA vs total RNA), reverse transcriptase (AMV vs MMLV), and primer usage on sequencing outcomes.
results: Unamplified sequencing detected more V-gene segments (112 vs 85-100 in amplified methods) and captured 98% of high-frequency CDR3s despite lower read counts. Amplified methods showed significant biases in V-gene detection and lower correlation with unamplified data (R²=0.45-0.68).
conclusion: Unamplified RNA sequencing provides a more comprehensive view of the antibody repertoire with fewer biases, making it suitable for immune monitoring in spaceflight where accurate assessment of immune status is critical.

learning_notes.note: Unamplified RNA sequencing detected 112 V-gene segments compared to only 85-100 segments detected by commercially amplified methods, demonstrating that amplification introduces significant biases that reduce repertoire comprehensiveness, which is critical for accurate immune monitoring in spaceflight.

Despite generating only 11,200 antibody reads versus 637,214-1,035,461 in amplified methods, the unamplified approach captured 98% of high-frequency CDR3 sequences, showing it efficiently identifies dominant immune clones relevant for monitoring immune competence during space missions.

The study revealed that mRNA as starting material increased read counts up to two orders of magnitude but introduced additional biases, while MMLV reverse transcriptase with random hexamer primers generally yielded higher quality results, informing optimal sample preparation for spaceflight studies.

Amplified methods failed to detect 13 V-gene segments that were consistently found in unamplified sequencing, with specific high-frequency genes like V4-1 and V2-6 being systematically underrepresented, highlighting critical gaps in amplified repertoire coverage.

Technical reproducibility was high within methods (R²=0.96-0.99 for technical replicates) but correlations between amplified and unamplified methods were only moderate (R²=0.45-0.68), indicating fundamental differences in repertoire representation that affect data interpretation.

CDR3 resampling efficiency was similar across methods (20-32% overlap between technical replicates), suggesting that depth of sequencing doesn't necessarily improve reproducibility, which has implications for designing efficient immune monitoring protocols with limited resources in space.

The research was NASA-funded (grants NNX13AN34G and NNX15AB45G) specifically for validating methods to assess immunoglobulin gene repertoires in tissues from spaceflight experiments, indicating direct relevance to NASA's immune system research objectives.
